Example:
type CacheStats struct {
    CachedUsers int
    TotalFeeds  int
    Hits        int64
    Misses      int64
    HitRate     float64  // Calculated: hits / (hits + misses)
}

func (uc *UnreadCache) Get(userID int) (map[int]int, bool) {
    // ... existing logic ...
    if hit {
        atomic.AddInt64(&uc.hits, 1)
    } else {
        atomic.AddInt64(&uc.misses, 1)
    }
    return result, hit
}

Benefits:
- Data-driven performance tuning
- Identify cache warming opportunities
- Monitor production effectiveness

Impact: Enhancement - improves observability
Priority: Low - nice to have for production monitoring

title: Implement cursor-based pagination for article loading
notes:
## Problem

Current pagination uses offset-based queries with unread_only filtering, which has fundamental issues when the underlying dataset changes:

1. User loads first 50 articles (offset=0)
2. User marks some as read
3. Server's unread query now returns different results for offset positions
4. Clicking 'Load More' with offset=50 can skip articles or show duplicates

## Current Workaround

Client-side duplicate detection using a Set of loaded article IDs. This prevents duplicates but doesn't solve the skipped articles problem.

## Ideal Solution

Implement cursor-based pagination using timestamps:

- Instead of offset, use before parameter with article timestamp/ID
- Example: /api/feeds/all/articles?limit=50&before=2025-10-13T18:30:00&unread_only=true
- Server returns articles published before the cursor, maintaining consistent ordering
- Works correctly even when articles are marked as read between requests

## Implementation

Backend changes needed:
- Modify GetUserArticlesPaginated in feed service to accept cursor parameter
- Change SQL query from OFFSET to WHERE published_at < ? with ORDER BY published_at DESC
- Return cursor value for next page in response

Frontend changes:
- Track cursor (timestamp of last article) instead of offset
- Pass cursor to subsequent requests

## Benefits

- No duplicate articles
- No skipped articles  
- Consistent pagination regardless of read/unread state changes
- Better performance (cursor queries faster than large offsets)
close_reason: Cursor-based pagination already implemented and verified. Added comprehensive test (TestCursorPaginationWithReadStateChanges) that confirms zero duplicates or skipped articles when marking articles as read between pagination requests. Backend uses {timestamp}_{id} cursors with proper indexing. Issue resolved.

title: Implement Cloud Tasks for async cron job processing
description:
Replace synchronous cron job handlers with Cloud Tasks to prevent excessive App Engine instance scaling while ensuring background work completes reliably.

Current problem:
- Cron jobs (feed refresh every 1h, cleanup every 24h) run synchronously
- Long-running operations keep App Engine instances alive
- Causes excessive instance scaling and unnecessary costs for low-traffic deployments
- Previous attempt to use background goroutines failed because App Engine kills goroutines when HTTP response completes

Affected endpoints:
- /cron/refresh-feeds (internal/handlers/feed_handler.go:303)
- /cron/cleanup-orphaned-articles (internal/handlers/feed_handler.go:346)
design:
Use Google Cloud Tasks to process cron work asynchronously:

1. Create Cloud Tasks queue (via Terraform or gcloud)
2. Update cron handlers to:
   - Enqueue task to Cloud Tasks
   - Return 200 OK immediately
   - Task worker endpoint processes the actual work
3. Implement task handler endpoints:
   - /tasks/refresh-feeds (actual feed processing)
   - /tasks/cleanup-orphaned-articles (actual cleanup)
4. Add authentication for task endpoints (verify X-CloudTasks-* headers)
5. Configure task queue with appropriate retry policies

Benefits:
- Cron handlers return immediately (< 100ms)
- App Engine doesn't keep instances running during long operations
- Tasks complete reliably even if instance shuts down
- Proper retry/error handling built into Cloud Tasks
- Reduces instance-hour costs by 30-50% for low-traffic deployments

References:
- https://cloud.google.com/tasks/docs/creating-appengine-handlers
- https://cloud.google.com/appengine/docs/standard/go/taskqueue/push/creating-handlers
acceptance_criteria:
- [ ] Cloud Tasks queue created and configured
- [ ] Cron handlers enqueue tasks and return immediately
- [ ] Task handler endpoints process work correctly
- [ ] Task endpoints properly authenticated (X-CloudTasks headers)
- [ ] Feed refresh completes successfully via Cloud Tasks
- [ ] Cleanup completes successfully via Cloud Tasks
- [ ] Error handling and retry logic tested
- [ ] App Engine instance count reduced for low-traffic periods
- [ ] No 500 errors in production after deployment

title: LOW: Session Fixation Vulnerability on Login
description:
**Location:** internal/handlers/auth_handler.go - Callback()

**Issue:** Sessions are not regenerated after successful authentication, allowing session fixation attacks. An attacker can set a victim's session ID before login, then hijack the authenticated session.

**Missing:** Session ID regeneration after authentication

**Risk:** LOW - Requires attacker to set victim's session cookie before authentication

**Recommendation:**
1. Delete old session after successful OAuth callback
2. Generate new session with new ID
3. Update session cookie with new ID

title: LOW: No Security Headers Configured
description:
**Location:** main.go - Missing security header middleware

**Issue:** The application does not set recommended security HTTP headers:
- X-Frame-Options (clickjacking protection)
- X-Content-Type-Options (MIME sniffing protection)  
- X-XSS-Protection (XSS filter)
- Strict-Transport-Security (HSTS)
- Content-Security-Policy (CSP)
- Referrer-Policy (referrer leakage)

**Risk:** LOW - Missing defense-in-depth layers

**Recommendation:**
Add security headers middleware:
```go
r.Use(func(c *gin.Context) {
    c.Header("X-Frame-Options", "DENY")
    c.Header("X-Content-Type-Options", "nosniff")
    c.Header("X-XSS-Protection", "1; mode=block")
    c.Header("Referrer-Policy", "strict-origin-when-cross-origin")
    if isProduction {
        c.Header("Strict-Transport-Security", "max-age=31536000; includeSubDomains")
    }
    c.Next()
})
```

Add context-aware cleanup for graceful shutdown
description:
Enhancement: Make cache cleanup goroutines context-aware for graceful application shutdown.

Locations:

Current implementation:
- Cleanup goroutines run indefinitely
- No graceful shutdown mechanism
- Could cause issues during deployment/restart

Recommended implementation:
1. Add Start(ctx context.Context) method
2. Use context for cleanup goroutine lifecycle
3. Support graceful shutdown

Example:
func (uc *UnreadCache) Start(ctx context.Context) {
    go uc.cleanupExpiredEntries(ctx)
}

func (uc *UnreadCache) cleanupExpiredEntries(ctx context.Context) {
    ticker := time.NewTicker(5 * time.Minute)
    defer ticker.Stop()
    
    for {
        select {
        case <-ticker.C:
            // ... cleanup logic
        case <-ctx.Done():
            return  // Graceful shutdown
        }
    }
}

Benefits:
- Cleaner shutdown behavior
- Better testing support
- More production-ready

Impact: Enhancement - improves production readiness
Priority: Low - nice to have for production deployments

title: Filter expired entries from cache stats
description:

- internal/cache/feed_list_cache.go:80-88

Problem:

Recommended fix for UnreadCache:
func (uc *UnreadCache) GetStats() CacheStats {
    uc.mu.RLock()
    defer uc.mu.RUnlock()

    now := time.Now()
    activeUsers := 0
    totalFeeds := 0
    
    for userID, counts := range uc.counts {
        if now.Before(uc.refreshAt[userID]) { // Only count valid entries
            activeUsers++
            totalFeeds += len(counts)
        }
    }

    return CacheStats{
        CachedUsers: activeUsers,
        TotalFeeds:  totalFeeds,
    }
}

Similar fix needed for FeedListCache.

Impact: Minor - improves observability accuracy
Priority: Medium - fix after critical memory leaks
